The city of Lumeris woke like a tuning fork.
From their high-perch alcove, the whole crystalline gorge shivered in Lira’s 
ears: tram rails humming in lazy chords, mana conduits thrumming like distant 
bees, and far below, the Elder Vault’s core note—an old, patient drone vibrating  
up through the geode spires. Her augmentation caught every frequency, rendering 
the dawn into a crowded choir.
On the floor between her and the narrow window lay a shallow dish of mana 
shards. Six pale slivers and dust. Their glow was the sickly color of overused 
spell-fire.
Lira counted them again, though they hadn’t inconveniently multiplied overnight.  
“One, two, three—don’t flicker at me—four, five, six, and crumbs,” she muttered,  
voice sharp with the effort of staying calm. The shards answered with a tired 
little pulse against her fingers.
Across the alcove, Cael’s cloak hung from a crystal peg, neatly folded over the 
peg’s prismatic arms. His heirloom chronoglyph dangled from the cloak’s inner 
loop, a palm-sized disk of clouded crystal, pulsing time in soft, steady beats. 
She heard it more than saw it—the comforting, tickless cadence that had always 
undercut the city’s chaos.
Her antenna-hair stirred restlessly at the sound, a long spill of shimmering 
strands that fell past her waist and sometimes further if she let it. Today it 
braided itself without her asking, filaments splitting and twining into narrow, 
questing tethers that brushed the air like curious fingertips, tasting mana 
currents through the chipped window.
“Nosy,” she scolded it under her breath, smoothing the living strands back over 
one shoulder. The hair warmed against her palm in mild protest. It was her best 
tool, her only real treasure—and the thing half the Vault’s senior enchanters 
would have sold their third-favorite relics to get a cut of.
Six shards and dust. Solstice-eve.
In the walkways outside, preparations were already ringing. Someone down-spire 
was stringing bottled starlight along a bridge; their clinks and the chirp of 
opening seals skittered through Lira’s hearing. Laughter bounced up from the 
ravine as a tramcar passed, its levitation plates chiming. There would be 
lantern processions tonight, public aura-dances, and—at the heart of it all—the 
Exchange.
Couples would step onto the central glass, gifts cupped in their hands, while 
their neighbors watched how much glow—and how much ridiculousness—they were 
willing to burn for love.
Lira glanced from the pathetic dish of shards to the chronoglyph’s gentle hum 
and felt her own aura shrink in on itself, a dimming she could almost hear. Cael  
deserved to stand among the bright ones, owning at least one gesture that made 
the gossips suck in breath before they laughed.
Her fingers tightened around the rim of the mana dish until the crystal bit her 
skin. “This isn’t even enough for a calibration charm,” she whispered. “Let 
alone—”
The Elder Vault’s drone wavered, just slightly, as some faraway engineer tuned a  
conduit. The slip prickled along her scalp. Her hair responded, braids loosening  
to fan out wider, filaments brushing the low ceiling, the window-frame, the 
chipped stone ledge that pretended to be a table. She winced at the volume: the 
conduits’ song rose, detail upon detail, every micro-hum insisting on being 
heard.
“Lira?” Cael’s voice drifted from the sleeping nook, muffled by the hanging bead

curtain. She’d been so intent on the dish she hadn’t heard him wake.
He emerged, barefoot, hair crushed on one side from the thin pallet. His aura—a 
faint, honest glow, like a lantern running on its last good shard—haloed him in 
soft amber. When he saw her on the floor with the mana dish, the light around 
him flickered with a question.
“You’re up early.” He stifled a yawn, then frowned at the shards. “Did the 
stipend come through?”
She pushed a stray filament behind her ear, willing her hair to stay still. “It 
came.” She tried for breezy, didn’t quite manage it. “Rent stepped in front of 
it. So did the tithe to keep the old man humming.” Her chin jerked toward the 
distant Elder Vault as if he could see through crystal walls.
Cael sank down beside her, the chronoglyph at his cloak ticking its gentle, 
private beat. He watched the six sad slivers, then her face. “We still have what  
we saved,” he said carefully.
“What you saved,” she corrected. “For—” For what you’re planning for me.
His aura wavered again; for a moment it brightened, then closed like a fist. 
“For later,” he said. “For emergencies. For if the conduits down-spire blow 
again and the guild decides junior tuners are more combustible than mana.”
Lira huffed something between a laugh and a scoff. “My love, they already 
decided that.”
He smiled despite himself. The small lines at the corners of his mouth softened 
her panic, just a little. He reached over and let his fingers drift through the 
ends of her antenna-hair. The filaments curled around his knuckles, sensing the 
familiar aura.
“I could pawn a few more hours at the Registry,” he said. “Take the night shift,  
log Solstice bindings while the smart ones are out burning theirs.”
“And be a ghost at our own Exchange?” Lira shook her head. The movement sent a 
faint, chiming rustle through her hair. “No. You’re not sacrificing sleep for a 
trinket. That would be absurd.”
She didn’t look at the chronoglyph when she said it.
Outside, a bell-crystal rang three times from some upper terrace, the sound 
shearing cleanly through the morning hum. Solstice countdown. Twelve hours until  
every couple in Lumeris stepped into the glow and showed the city exactly how 
reckless they were willing to be.
Lira stared at the dish, then at Cael’s hand still tangled in her hair. In her 
skull, mana-songs surged louder, unbearable with possibility and lack.
“Cael,” she said quietly, “if you had nothing for me tonight. If we stood there 
with empty hands, just… aura to aura. Would you feel—less?”
His eyes jumped to hers, startled. “Of you?” He shook his head at once, almost 
vehement. “Lira, no. I’d feel relieved I hadn’t done anything catastrophically 
foolish.” A ghost of a grin. “The city would be disappointed, but they’ll 
survive.”
“Liar,” she said. “You love those stories as much as anyone.”
He conceded that with a tilt of his head. “I do like watching other people 
overclock themselves.” His thumb stroked a single filament, and his gaze went 
distant for a heartbeat, as if weighing something unsaid. “We’ll manage,” he 
finished softly. “We always do.”

He rose, brushing crystal dust from his trousers, and ducked back behind the 
curtain to dress for the Registry. His footsteps made the floor sing faintly 
under Lira’s palms.
As the beads rattled closed behind him, her hair shivered with a thought of its 
own, splitting into two thick braids that coiled around her arms like question 
marks.
Six shards. Dust. A husband who would rather go without than see her dim herself  
for his sake.
Lira sat very still in the middle of their narrow, humming world, listening to 
the ache in the mana around her, until one clear, terrible idea rose out of the 
noise and would not leave.
By the time Cael stepped back out, wrapping his cloak and clipping the 
chronoglyph to its inner loop, her mind was fixed.
“Walk you to the tram?” she asked, voice almost normal.
He kissed her forehead, his aura warming her skin. “You’ll be late to the 
Vault.”
“The conduits can hum without me for one shift,” she said. Her hair tightened in  
on itself, braids knotting like nerves. “I have… an errand in the market.”
Out on the glass walkway, bottled starlights bobbed in the rising drafts, and 
far below, in the ring of stalls above the mana ravine, the Relic Brokers were 
already lighting their incense.
They rode down together until the tram forked—one line diving toward the Elder 
Vault, the other curving toward the market-ring—and when they parted on the 
platform, Lira’s decision had hardened to something bright and dangerous in her 
chest.
Mist beaded on the glass walkway as Lira stepped off the tramcar, breath 
ghosting the surface in nervous bursts. The rail beneath her boots hummed with 
stored mana, a note so pure it stabbed her over-tuned ears. Every conduit, every  
lantern of bottled starlight, every passing aura-thrum of a stranger jangled in 
her skull like an orchestra tuning all at once.
She should have been descending toward the Elder Vault’s underlevels, wrench and  
incense-kit in hand. Instead she turned the other way, toward the market-ring 
that clung to the ravine wall like a band of glinting barnacles.
“Relic broking, licensed and insured,” sang a crystal chime overhead as she 
entered the ring. Stalls of carved geode crowded the narrow curve, each haloed 
in softly glowing sigils. The air smelled of hot quartz dust, old incense, and 
the faint coppery tang of mana about to change hands.
Couples shuffled past her, fingers laced, auras braided in smug little twists. 
Lira caught whispers.
“Sold his spine-rod for a song crystal, can you imagine—”
“Overclocked by love, that one. Adorable. Idiotic.”
She tucked her own dim aura closer, hugging her threadbare coat, and forced 
herself to look up. There—midway along the ring, wedged between a pawn-chant 
kiosk and a stall promising “ethical curse extractions”—hung a modest slate of 
obsidian etched with neat silver script:
MASTER VORIN, LICENSED RELIC BROKER. NO REFUNDS ON REGRETS.

Beneath, a smaller sigil flickered: DE-BINDINGS PERFORMED WHILE-U-WAIT.
Her stomach dropped like a mis-keyed lift cage.
The stall itself was barely the size of her alcove at home. Racks of thin 
crystal coffers lined the walls, each holding coils of hair, rings, slivers of 
bone, teeth—little pieces of people glowing faintly, tagged with dangling 
parchment slips. A low counter divided customer from wares, its surface crowded 
with inkpots, stamped seals, and a small brass brazier breathing out curls of 
lavender and ash.
Master Vorin looked up from a ledger, quill pausing mid-stroke. He was younger 
than she’d imagined, with neatly braided beard-rings tinkling like soft bells 
when he tilted his head. His own aura was a steady, practical glow: bright 
enough to command respect, not so bright anyone would call it romantic.
“Antenna-hair,” he said, before she could speak. His gaze had gone at once to 
the waterfall of shimmering filaments cascading past her shoulders. “Living 
conduit type. Vault-tuned by the sound of it.” He sniffed, very slightly. “Buzz 
of elder-core all over you.”
Lira’s hands flew up, fingers tangling in the strands as if to hide them. The 
hair twitched under her touch, sympathetic, tiny filaments questing like feelers  
toward the stall’s hum.
“I—” Her voice cracked. “I need mana shards.”
“As do we all.” Vorin’s smile was polite, thin as mica. “What are you offering?”
She swallowed. Her throat felt full of powdered crystal.
“My hair,” she said. “Most of it.”
The brazier’s smoke seemed to thicken between them. Somewhere outside, a tramcar  
slid past with a shivering whine. Her hair shivered back, amplifying it until 
the sound pressed needles against her eardrums.
Vorin leaned forward, the bells in his beard chiming. “Soulbound to you from 
birth?”
“Yes.”
“Registry mark?”
She tugged her collar aside to show the faint sigil burned at the base of her 
neck: a spiral of tiny runes, pulsing slow. He made a note in his ledger, then 
slid a thin, bluish slip of crystal toward her.
“Standard de-binding consent form,” he said. “Initial here, here, and here that 
you understand permanent loss of resonance bandwidth, possible aura-dimming, 
degraded professional capacity, and all downstream consequences including but 
not limited to career stagnation, amplified loneliness, and post-ritual romantic  
distress.”
He said it the way she listed conduit faults on a work ticket. Routine. Boring.
Her hand shook as she took the stylus. The crystal warmed to her touch, blooming  
with her aura-signature. She thought of Cael’s face that morning, lit faintly by  
the chronoglyph’s runes as he joked about feeding the Elder “old man” another 
day of their pay. Thought of the public Exchange-balcony tomorrow, where every 
couple’s offering would flare or fizzle under a hundred watching eyes.
He deserved more than a fizzle.

She signed.
Vorin checked the glowing marks, then nodded and rose. “Head in the ring,” he 
said, gesturing to a hoop of bone-white crystal suspended from a hinged arm. 
Runes along its inner edge winked awake as it swung down toward her.
Lira stepped close. The hoop’s chill kissed her cheeks as it settled around her 
neck like a noose made by bureaucrats.
“Last chance to back out,” Vorin offered, voice almost gentle. “The market for 
antenna-hair is odd this quarter. You could wait. Save mana the slow way.”
The slow way—skipping meals, double shifts in the underlevels, Cael pretending 
not to notice her exhaustion. Handing him a sad, token charm and watching his 
careful smile.
“No,” she said. “Do it.”
“Very well.”
He pinched a pinch of resin into the brazier. The smoke thickened, threads of 
violet and silver curling up to brush her dangling filaments. A low, clear tone 
rang from the hoop, resonating down her hair, through her skull, into her teeth.  
The runes at her neck prickled hot, then icy.
There was a moment—one thin, stretched instant—when her hair seemed to cling to 
her, every strand a tiny hand begging not to be let go.
“I’m sorry,” she whispered, whether to it or to herself she wasn’t sure.
Vorin’s knife flashed: not metal, but a planar shard of obsidian etched with 
severance sigils. He slid it through the fall of shimmering filaments with a 
practised motion.
Sound vanished.
The ceaseless city-hum, the Elder Vault’s far-off organ-drone, even the flutter 
of other people’s auras—gone, ripped away so fast her balance threw itself into 
nothing. Her knees buckled. She grabbed the counter, fingers scraping ink-
stained glass.
Behind the ring, cut hair poured into the waiting coffer in a slow, luminous 
spill. It hit the crystal with a faint, dead clink, like rain on a tombstone.
“There we are,” Vorin said, as if unclogging a drain. He adjusted the hoop away 
from her throat. The air felt wrong, muffled, like cotton stuffed in her soul.
Her head felt suddenly light, exposed. She raised a hand, finding only a ragged,  
short fringe where the living weight had once swung down her back. Her 
fingertips tingled with phantom threads.
“How much?” she asked hoarsely.
Vorin weighed the coffer on a set of rune-scales. Numbers flickered in the air, 
little ghostly columns of profit and loss. He clicked his tongue. “Resonance 
quality is excellent. Length, impressive. Vault-tuned premium.” He jotted 
another figure. “Twenty refined shards,” he said at last. “And I’ll cover the 
de-binding incense.”
He counted them out into a small pouch, each shard ringing faintly as it dropped
—bright, hard notes in the new quiet of her hearing. He set the pouch on the 
counter between them.

Lira stared. Tiny, faceted bits of frozen spell-capacity. Enough to buy a 
chronoglyph chain worthy of Cael’s heirloom—a masterwork that would sing in 
perfect time with the Elder’s beacons.
Enough to buy back her courage.
She reached for the pouch. Her shortened hair stirred at the movement, as if 
trying to rise and listen and finding itself woefully insufficient.
Vorin cleared his throat. “Miss Lira. I am obliged to remind you: no refunds on 
regrets.”
She cinched the pouch shut with numb fingers and tucked it inside her coat, 
against the dim flutter of her heart.
“I’ll…manage,” she said.
As she stepped back onto the market-ring, the city’s song came to her dull and 
distant, like music through a wall. Somewhere far above, the Elder Vault’s 
monolith groaned softly as its conduits flexed for another cycle.
Lira set her jaw and turned toward the jeweler’s quarter, where master chains 
hung like captured constellations behind warded glass. Each step carried her 
further from the hair she’d left behind and closer to the gift she could almost 
see shining at Cael’s throat.
She did not look back at the stall where her living relic lay coiled and cooling  
in a crystal box, already a line item in someone else’s ledger.
By the time the upper-spire bells marked late afternoon, the chain was hers, its  
weight against her palm a mingling of pride and loss as she rode the tram back 
up toward home.
The crystal door to their alcove stuck, as always, in the warped frame.
Lira shouldered it anyway. The glass scraped with a shrill note she could barely  
hear now, then gave, spilling her into the narrow room perched over the blue-
black ravine. Bottled starlight bobbed in their only lantern, throwing pale 
facets over the pallet, the chipped kettle, the single hook where Cael’s work-
robe usually hung.
Empty.
The conduits along the wall whispered faintly, threads of mana sliding past in 
tones that once rang in her bones. Now they were only a distant tinnitus. She 
reached up by reflex for the thick weight of antenna-braids that should have 
been there, and her fingers met the blunt, unfamiliar stubble of her shorn 
scalp.
“You bought the chain,” she told the room, because if she did not say it aloud 
it might turn into a mistake. Her voice came out thinner than she liked. “You 
absolute, ridiculous man. You’re going to glow when you see it.”
She opened her fist. The masterwork chronoglyph chain pooled into her palm, cool  
and heavy, runes etched so fine they looked like hairline cracks in starlight. 
The jeweler had demonstrated how it would sync to Cael’s watch, how the glyphs 
would catch the Elder Vault’s time-beacons and paint predictions on the air.
She had nodded as if she could still hear those beacons clearly.
Bootsteps hissed along the outer glass walkway. Lira’s diminished hearing caught  
only a smear of sound, but her aura prickled a split-second before the latch 
turned. She hid the chain behind her back on instinct.

The door scraped again. Cael slipped inside sideways, as if he didn’t quite 
believe the alcove was large enough to admit him. Chill mist curled around his 
ankles before the door thunked shut.
“Lira?” He smelled of dusted crystal and ledger ink, the familiar scents that 
said he had spent too long hunched over the Soulbound Registry. The faint hum 
that always wrapped him—the steady pulse of his chronoglyph at his belt—was 
gone.
In its absence, the silence roared.
She watched his gaze climb from her boots to her throat, then up. It hit the 
bare curve of her skull like a physical impact. His pupils widened. For a 
heartbeat he simply stood, hand still braced on the door, breath caught in his 
chest as if someone had closed a valve.
Her own lungs forgot their work.
She had imagined anger, or horror, or that faintly pinched politeness people 
showed the magically anemic. What she had not rehearsed was this stunned 
stillness.
“I—” Lira’s hand flew to her head, fingers splaying over the rough regrowth. 
“Before you say anything, it’s legal. Vorin filed the de-binding himself. No 
security flags, no curses, just… shorter.” The last word wobbled.
Cael blinked once, twice. The pale threads of his aura, usually neat and 
contained, frayed outward like smoke.
“You cut it,” he said, very softly.
“Sold it,” she corrected, because precision mattered to him. “Most of it. We 
needed— I needed mana. For Solstice.” Heat rose in her face. “I won’t be useless  
at work, they’ll just have to keep me off the high resonance lines for a while, 
and my hearing— it’s only half-gone, really, and the rest of me is quite intact,  
so if you’re going to faint, do it away from the edge, Cael.”
His hand left the door. He took a step, then another, as if crossing a fragile 
span where any wrong move would send the whole alcove tumbling into the ravine. 
Up close, the fine lines of fatigue around his mouth were deeper. His eyes, 
though, stayed fixed on her, not skittering around her to the bare walls or the 
empty conduit sockets.
“You sold your hair,” he repeated. “Lira, why?”
“For you.” The words came out before she could blunt them. “I had one point 
three shards after tithe and rent. One point three. I am your wife, not a dim 
paper lantern. You wear your father’s chronoglyph on a frayed cord you have 
knotted thirteen times. So I—” She yanked her hand from behind her back.
The chain spilled between them, catching the lantern’s weak light. Its runes 
flared faintly in recognition of a nearby time-source, then guttered, confused.
“I got you something worthy.” Her throat burned. “A proper tether. Mana-
conductive, Elder-calibrated. The jeweler tuned it to your glyph’s hum. You can 
wear it outside your robe, like the senior scribes do. People will see what you 
carry.”
Silence fell again, thick as felt.
Cael did not reach for the chain.
Instead his jaw moved, as if he were chewing a string of syllables he didn’t 
want to spit out. His hand slid inside his robe and fumbled with something at

his side, then drew out a small velvet case the color of bottled midnight.
Lira’s stomach flipped. “You… you bought yourself a box?”
He huffed an almost-laugh that broke on the edges. “Not for me.” He turned the 
case in his fingers, not yet opening it. “I thought you’d still have…” His gaze 
flicked, quick and helpless, to the rough cap of her hair.
Guilt washed through her in a cold sheet. “Cael?” she whispered.
He snapped the clasp.
Inside, on black velvet, lay combs: three slender arcs of crystal and silver 
filigree, teeth so fine they could part light, each spine etched with runes that  
pulsed a soft, familiar pattern. Her pattern. Tiny resonance-knots waited where 
her antenna-braids should have anchored them.
The world tilted. She reached out but stopped before touching them, as if they 
were some delicate, endangered thing.
“You—” Her voice cracked; she tried again. “You attuned them to my hair.”
“I sat in the enchanter’s stall for two hours while they made you hum into a 
crystal jar,” he said. There was an edge of dazed humor under the words. “They 
said only a fool would tune combs this precise for hair that already does 
everything. I told them that was the point.”
Lira’s laugh came out as a strangled sound. “Cael, I haven’t got hair enough to 
snare dust motes, much less runes.” She scrubbed at her eyes with her free hand.  
“They’re beautiful. And entirely useless.”
“Only if your gift had somehow vanished entirely.” His smile was crooked, 
desperate. “Your aura’s still… it’s still you.”
The chain between her fingers suddenly weighed as much as the entire Elder 
Vault.
“Cael,” she said slowly, “where did you get the mana for these? We barely 
covered tithe this month. Don’t tell me the Registry handed out festival 
bonuses; I do work for the Elder AI, I would have heard it complaining.”
His gaze dropped to the chronoglyph’s usual resting place at his belt. The empty  
air there seemed to pulse.
“I had something the enchanter wanted,” he said. “Something old, but well-kept. 
A family relic with steady timekeeping and a very patient hum.” He tried for 
lightness and failed. “They called it charmingly obsolete.”
The air thinned. Lira’s augment, dulled as it was, found only the hollow where 
the chronoglyph’s song should have been.
“You… de-registered it.” The chain slipped a fraction in her fingers. “Your 
chronoglyph.”
He nodded once. “Traded it at Vorin’s, actually. He liked the probability band; 
said it would fetch a good spell-price in the upper tiers.” His mouth twisted at  
her flinch. “They unsoulbound it clean. I signed all the clauses. No curses, no 
recall. Just… gone.”
Her knees felt unreliable. She leaned back until the cool crystal wall caught 
her.
“So,” she said, because if she didn’t keep speaking the world would dissolve. 
“You sold your chronoglyph to buy combs for hair I no longer have. I sold my

hair to buy a chain for a chronoglyph you no longer own.”
The absurdity hung between them, fragile and luminous, like one of the city’s 
floating lanterns just before a gust.
Cael looked at the combs, then at her shorn head, then at the chain sparking 
faint, lost runes in her hand. A sound came out of him—half laugh, half 
something like a sob.
“In the ledgers,” he murmured, “this would be classed as catastrophic 
inefficiency.”
Her own laugh arrived then, bubbling up past the tightness in her chest. Once it  
started, she couldn’t stop. It shook her shoulders, made the starlight lantern 
sway wildly, threw fractured gleams over combs that would never tame long braids  
and a chain that would never brace a watch.
Cael watched her, and slowly his shoulders unhitched. The tight weave of his 
aura loosened, brightening by degrees until it brushed against hers like the 
touch of a hand.
He stepped closer, so close the comb case and the chain and their two foolish, 
empty hands almost knocked together.
“We’re idiots,” Lira gasped, wiping at her eyes. “Bright-fools, the gossipers 
will call us. ‘Did you hear about the engineer who sold her relic to dress the 
watch that isn’t there?’”
“And the scribe who traded time itself for hair he can’t even comb,” Cael added.  
His smile was unsteady but real now. “Optimization would have us flogged.”
“The Elder AI will log us as a bug,” she said, feeling the wild grin still 
tugging at her mouth. “Two nodes of extreme wastefulness. Recommend patch: 
prohibit love from accessing relic registry.”
“Too late for that.” His fingers, finally, brushed the back of her hand, warm 
and callused. He closed them gently around the chain, not to take it—just to 
trap it between them. “Lira. Look at me.”
She did. His gaze held no pity, no calculation, only an ache that matched the 
hollow in her own chest and something bright threaded through it.
“You’re not a dim lantern,” he said quietly. “With or without the hair. Or the 
over-tuned ears. Or anything that can be listed on a ledger line.” His thumb 
traced the ridge of her knuckles. “You walked into Vorin’s stall and saw 
whatever fine print he put in front of you and signed anyway. For me.”
“You sold your father’s relic,” she shot back, the words too sharp, too hot. 
“That hum has been beside you since you were ten. You gave that up so I could— 
what? Hear less? Stand in a market and be told I’m already too much?”
He chuckled, low. “So you could have tools that might have made the hum kinder.”  
He held up the combs a little. “They’re jokes now. Beautiful ones. But I don’t 
regret the impulse.”
Her protest stuttered. The conduits along the wall seemed, for a breath, to sing  
louder. Or perhaps that was just the sudden surge of warmth between them, 
pushing back the edges of her dulled hearing.
Through the ceiling, faint as dust motes, the Elder Vault’s main node hummed. 
Her augment translated it as numbers once, then as weather, then—just for an 
instant—as a spike of raw brightness tagged in some clerical subroutine.
“If Vorin tallies this up,” Cael said, “I imagine the net mana loss is

appalling.”
“Catastrophic,” she agreed.
They stood like that, ridiculous and empty-handed and somehow more full than 
when they’d walked into their respective stalls. The combs glowed softly in 
their velvet cradle. The chain’s runes flickered with frustrated readiness.
Lira inhaled. The choice sat in front of her like a lever: cling to the waste, 
to the ledger of what was gone, or… something else.
“Take it,” she said, curling his fingers more firmly around the chain until he 
had no choice but to grasp it. “Even without the chronoglyph. Let it sit in your  
pocket. Let it annoy you with all the things it can’t do. Let it remind you that  
someone thought your time was worth dressing.”
He stared at her, some new question forming in his eyes.
“And you,” he said slowly, as if matching a move in a game he hadn’t known they 
were playing, “will keep these.” He lifted the comb case toward her. “Tuck them 
somewhere impractical. On the wall. Under your pillow. Until the day your hair 
grows long enough to snag a single rune.”
Her breath hitched.
Outside, a gust rose from the ravine, setting the whole alcove trembling on its 
crystalline braces. Lantern-light wavered. Far above, the Elder Vault’s optic 
eye pivoted, registering an anomalous flare—two weak auras burning suddenly, 
stupidly bright.
Lira closed her hand around the combs, thin teeth biting gently into her palm.
“Then what?” she asked.
Cael’s answer hovered on his lips, the next heartbeat stretching out before it 
could fall.
The flare fades slowly from the alcove, like the afterimage of lightning on 
closed eyes.
Cracked crystal walls stop resonating and settle back into their usual murmur. 
Outside, tramcars hiss along levitation rails, distant and ordinary again. In 
the hush that follows the aura-surge, Lira and Cael are left sitting cross-
legged on the woven glass mat, knees touching, surrounded by the ridiculous 
remains of their grand intentions.
The chronoglyph chain lies across Lira’s palm—a loop of pale platinum runes that  
still think they belong to something. Beside it, the velvet case yawns open, its  
resonance-combs glinting, teeth keen and thirsty for hair that no longer exists.
Lira’s cropped head feels naked in the draft from the ravine. Without her 
antenna-hair, the city’s song is muffled, as if she has stuffed wool into her 
augmented ears. For the first time since childhood, the Elder Vault’s low, 
omnipresent hum is only a suggestion, not a chorus.
“Well,” Cael says at last, voice hoarse from laughing too hard, “we have 
successfully optimized ourselves into decorative scrap metal.”
Lira snorts, then clamps a hand over her mouth, shoulders shaking. A stray 
filament, no longer prehensile, tickles her brow. “Don’t,” she whispers. “If I 
start again I’ll never stop.”
He studies her silhouette, the fragile new sharpness of it. The absence where 
her halo of hair used to spike and curl, catching every mote of starlight, makes

his chest ache with an odd mixture of grief and wonder.
“It suits you,” he says.
She gives him a flat look. “You are a liar and a bad one.”
“It suits the person I married,” he amends. “The one who thinks, ‘How can I 
catastrophically rearrange my life to give Cael one shiny thing for Solstice.’ 
Very on brand.”
Her laugh this time is smaller, edged. “You sold the chronoglyph.” She draws the  
words out slowly, like probing a bruise. “Your family’s relic. The only thing 
that ever told you when to stop working and come home. You…really did that.”
His hand goes automatically to the empty place at his belt where the crystal 
disk always pulsed. Fingers find only worn robe cloth.
“Vorin made me sign six scrolls,” he says lightly. “You’d have appreciated the 
ritual design. Clause twelve: ‘Client acknowledges long-term increases in 
temporal confusion and nostalgia.’”
Lira closes her fingers around the chain. Its idle runes thrum faintly against 
her skin, seeking a time-beacon that isn’t there. “I used the same Vorin,” she 
murmurs. “For this.” Her free hand grazes the back of her neck where the 
unsoulbinding sigils still tingle. “He warned me about ‘permanent resonance-
bandwidth reduction and post-transaction romantic regret.’”
“Did he say it like it was a side effect or a selling point?” Cael asks.
“Both.” She looks up at him, eyes shining in the star-lantern light. “I thought 
I was being…grand. Noble. A proper Bright-Fool.”
“You are,” he says simply.
Silence settles, companionable and strange. The alcove hums with low-grade mana 
from their pitiful wall conduit. Their interlaced auras—thinner now, a bit 
tattered—glow a soft, steady blue that tints the air between them.
“I keep thinking,” Lira says slowly, words careful as she picks them from the 
air, “about what the neighbors will say when they hear. ‘Did you see them? Sold 
their best relics and ended up with nothing that works. Overclocked by love and 
underpowered by brains.’”
Cael shrugs, the motion small but decisively dismissive. “Let them. The city was  
hungry for a new anecdote. Might as well give them something quality.”
“Quality failure,” she corrects.
“Premium-grade,” he agrees.
Her gaze drifts toward the ceiling where hair-thin mana veins thread the 
crystal. She can almost—but not quite—hear their song. “Do you…miss it? 
Already?”
“The chronoglyph?” He considers. The steady heartbeat of the relic had been his 
one reliable rhythm, his father’s palm in memory, his grandfather’s, stretching 
back down the line. “Yes. But it’s odd. The quiet isn’t empty.”
She tilts her head. “What is it, then?”
He reaches across the narrow space and places two fingers under her chin, 
drawing her attention back. “A bit like this,” he says. “Sitting with you. Not 
knowing what time it is. Knowing I don’t especially care.”

Lira swallows. Her augmented ears, denied the Elder AI’s endless murmur, lock 
onto the subtler sound of Cael’s pulse, the air whispering through his lungs. 
It’s messier than any calibrated engine beat. It’s perfect.
“I thought,” she confesses, voice nearly lost under a passing tram’s whoosh, “if  
I didn’t give you something that matched the chronoglyph, it would prove I 
didn’t love you as much as you loved it. Or as much as all those bright, 
balanced couples out there love each other.”
“Balanced?” He laughs quietly. “You’ve read too many aura-theory pamphlets. 
Those couples hoard their best relics and toss each other spark-candles and 
poetry. We just…tossed the relics.”
His hand falls, hesitates, then traces the ragged line where her hair ends. His 
fingers come away humming faintly, a ghost of the old resonance.
“Lira,” he says, more serious now, “do you regret it?”
She looks down at the chain again, then at the small burn marks on her wrists 
from Vorin’s severing sigils. Her life’s work was tuned to the city’s song; she 
has sliced away half her capacity to hear it.
“I regret that I won’t catch every flicker of the Elder’s moods anymore,” she 
answers. “That I’ll mishear a conduit and some senior engineer will tut at me. I  
regret the migraine that unsoulbinding gave me.” She takes a breath. “But giving  
that power to you—to something for you—felt…right. Like finally pointing my gift  
at the one conduit that mattered.”
Cael’s throat tightens. Somewhere deep below, the Elder Vault’s main monolith 
adjusts a parameter, its lone optic swiveling as it logs a faint, persisting 
anomaly: localized aura-brightening despite quantifiable resource loss. Flag: 
non-optimal yet high-satisfaction event.
“Then I don’t see a problem,” he says.
Her mouth curves, reluctant, touched by mischief. “Aside from the small detail 
that neither of us has a functioning primary relic anymore.”
“Ah.” He considers the chain, the combs, the bare alcove. “We do have one.”
She blinks. “If you say ‘love’ I will throw you off this walkway.”
“I was going to say ‘jointly filed aura-tax exemption,’” he deadpans. “Love is 
implied.”
She shoves his shoulder, but her body leans into the contact. The glass mat 
creaks softly beneath them.
“Look,” he says, more practical now. “You still hear better than any other tuner  
in the underlevels, even half-shorn. I still read the Elder’s spreadsheets 
faster than my section head, with or without a ticking rock. We are not 
helpless. Just…eccentric.”
“In a city that runs on eccentricity,” she muses.
He nods toward the useless relics between them. “We’ll repurpose them. The chain  
can anchor our door ward. No one will ever steal our disappointments.”
“And the combs?” she asks.
He studies their iridescent teeth. “Wall art. Or we wait. Your hair will grow. 
Not to what it was, maybe. But some. Enough for a very small, very powerful 
antenna-mess.”

The idea lands in her like warm mana. Her hair may never reclaim its full, 
intricate lattice; part of her capacity is gone by contract and ritual. But not 
all. Some futures, she realizes, still hum at the edges of perception.
“Vorin did say the cut ends can’t be rebound,” she murmurs, half to herself. “He  
didn’t say anything about new growth.”
“Relic broker oversight,” Cael says. “Tragic hole in the fine print.”
Their eyes meet, and for a suspended moment the alcove seems to tilt around that  
shared, dawning amusement.
“I suppose,” Lira says, “we’ve found the one mana-source the Elder can’t ledger 
properly.”
“Which one is that?”
She reaches across the relics, curls her fingers into his, and feels their tired  
auras mesh, brightening by a shade.
“Us,” she says. “Stupid, bright-fool us.”
Beneath them, the Elder AI marks another minor spike and attaches a note to its 
own record: Case Study #1007-BF—Evidence suggests that deliberate, impractical 
generosity yields disproportionate subjective fulfillment. Optimization 
parameters under review.
In the tiny alcove above the mist, unaware of this bureaucratic canonization, 
Lira squeezes Cael’s hand and levers herself to her feet.
“Come on,” she says, offering him the other hand. “Solstice lamps are still lit.  
We can at least go watch everyone else waste mana on fireworks.”
“And drink free guild punch,” he adds, taking her hand and rising with her.
“Obviously.” She hooks the chronoglyph chain around her own neck for now, its 
empty length cool against her throat. Cael tucks the combs carefully into his 
belt pouch like contraband.
They step out onto the narrow glass walkway, into the drifting starlight and the  
chorus of distant, foolish celebrations, their dimmed yet intertwining auras 
casting one steady, climbing glow as they go to join the other Bright-Fools of 
Lumeris.
